Rush Rules Submitted
New rush dates have been scheduled for next
year by the Committee on Undergraduate Affairs in
response to a proposal made by the IFC, and the IFC
has returned with a tentative set of rush rules.
The decision was made by the new administrative arm as a result of consideration given to the
change suggested by the IFC on the basis that the
dates originally scheduled would conflict with midterm examinations.
A new agreement has subsequently been anounced, accepting the IFC proposal and reading as
follows:
1. Fraternities may have three week ends for
parties, beginning the second week end after the
start of the second term.
2. Rush week will be the first week in March.
The letter also states that fraternities must
now present their detailed plans for next year to
Dean Morrill and that "The continuation of this
agreed set of dates for fraternity rushing will depend
upon the ability of the fraternities to develop a careful and workable program."

meeting last Friday, the following rules were adopted
for the coming year.
1. No freshman will be allowed in a fraternity
house until rushing officially begins except as approved by the IFC.

rules for members of the Faculties of Philosophy and the

the Board of Trustees and the
President of the University.
The rules, which have been in

promotion to a higher rank.
Professional Tenure
According to the specified
rules, the rank of professor shall
carry permanent tenure, except
in those cases where a special
appointment is made by mutual
agreement of the professor and
the University.
Tenure for associate professors

four years' service at that level
at the Johns Hopkins University.

professor will have term appointments not exceeding a total of six consecutive years at
Johns Hopkins.

rank of assistant professor for
more than seven consecutive
years, or the rank of instructor
for more than three consecutive
years.

a total of more than seven consecutive years.

of the tenth year of consecutive
service at the University whether
or not they will be given permanent tenure.

We Need Women
A combination of a winning lacrosse team and the
awareness of summer vaction just ahead has seemed
to inject that undergraduate body with some kind of
spirit that has been lacking on this campus for many
years and which appears to be anything but unhealthy.
We submit, that if there is any way to make this a
permanent addition to the Hopkins campus, coeducation is it.
In earnestness, we suggest that some committee
formed
to study such a prospect. It would seem that
he
the addition of women to a men's school would tio much
more than boost the morale of the student body. It
would most probably boost the academic standing of
the undergraduate body by increasing the number of
top applicants.
But further, the University, we feel, may have some
responsibility to the community to open its doors to all
qualified students who wish to attend. It is the only
university of great stature in Baltimore, one of the
nation's largest cities. With this academic monopoly,
exclusiveness ought not be in order.
We don't know what significant changes or expenses
would be incurred to carry out this suggestion, but if
It is a possibility, it certainly ought to be investigated.

Thoughts From Below
We would like to suggest a further step in the
university's program to cheer up its undergraduates.
Could it not cater to the discriminating taste of the
Hopkins community and provide university funds to
onderwrite some really first class functions on campus?
There has, for instance, been some rather nebulous talk
of bringing Ray Charles to Hopkins for a concert or a
dance. There is little doubt that he would draw a large
enthusiastic crowd; certainly no money would he lost on
such a venture. It would therefore cost the university,
in effect, nothing, were it to allow a student organization
the funds to bring about an entertainment of this nature.
Perhaps our view is oversimplified but we see no
reason why money cannot be released to sponsor undergraduate affairs. If judiciously administered such a
policy would be no financial loss to the university and a
great benefit to undergraduate morale.

Are They Kidding?
Joe Permit° informs us (see this week's correspondence) that he and the Cotillion Board are planning a big
week end next spring. In spite of our enthusiasm at
the prospect of a real college weekend at Hopkins we
must register a cry of alarm at some of the proposed
arrangements.
It is hard to believe that a band as insipid as Ray
Connif's is being seriously considered. Should such a
lack of taste permeate the planning of the entire weekend
the whole purpose of the event would be defeated.
Equally distressing are the projected financial arrangements, most of which appear tenuous indeed.
Neither the Administration nor the Alumni Association
is noted for its liberality in financing undergraduate
affairs, and to expect the local girls schools to pay part
of the costs is plain silly. Why should Goucher, Mount
Saint Agnes or Notre Dame invest in a function which
will benefit a small fraction of their students at best?
The Cotillion Board has a good idea on its hands.
It would he a shame if it were to fail because of mismanagement and an unrealistic approach to the problems
involved.

Dignitas Pro Graduafione
We are happy to note that the University has
invited Julius Stratton, President of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, to speak at commencement
exercises this June.
Too many universities have in recent years tried
to get the biggest political "attraction" available to address their June graduates. The University is quite right
in stepping out of this game.
Graduation is not a big show and should not be
treated as a publicity gimmick. It is the culmination
of advanced studies and should he held with academic
dignity.

awareness of summer vaction just ahead has seemed
to inject that undergraduate body with some kind of
spirit that has been lacking on this campus for many
years and which appears to be anything but unhealthy.
We submit, that if there is any way to make this a

In earnestness, we suggest that some committee
formed

the undergraduate body by increasing the number of

But further, the University, we feel, may have some
responsibility to the community to open its doors to all
qualified students who wish to attend. It is the only

nation's largest cities. With this academic monopoly,

Thoughts From Below
We would like to suggest a further step in the
university's program to cheer up its undergraduates.
Could it not cater to the discriminating taste of the
Hopkins community and provide university funds to
onderwrite some really first class functions on campus?
There has, for instance, been some rather nebulous talk
of bringing Ray Charles to Hopkins for a concert or a
dance. There is little doubt that he would draw a large
enthusiastic crowd; certainly no money would he lost on
such a venture. It would therefore cost the university,
in effect, nothing, were it to allow a student organization
the funds to bring about an entertainment of this nature.
Perhaps our view is oversimplified but we see no
reason why money cannot be released to sponsor undergraduate affairs. If judiciously administered such a
policy would be no financial loss to the university and a
great benefit to undergraduate morale.

Are They Kidding?
Joe Permit° informs us (see this week's correspondence) that he and the Cotillion Board are planning a big
week end next spring. In spite of our enthusiasm at
the prospect of a real college weekend at Hopkins we
must register a cry of alarm at some of the proposed
arrangements.
It is hard to believe that a band as insipid as Ray
Connif's is being seriously considered. Should such a
lack of taste permeate the planning of the entire weekend
the whole purpose of the event would be defeated.
Equally distressing are the projected financial arrangements, most of which appear tenuous indeed.
Neither the Administration nor the Alumni Association
is noted for its liberality in financing undergraduate
affairs, and to expect the local girls schools to pay part
of the costs is plain silly. Why should Goucher, Mount
Saint Agnes or Notre Dame invest in a function which
will benefit a small fraction of their students at best?
The Cotillion Board has a good idea on its hands.
It would he a shame if it were to fail because of mismanagement and an unrealistic approach to the problems
involved.

Dignitas Pro Graduafione

invited Julius Stratton, President of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, to speak at commencement
exercises this June.
Too many universities have in recent years tried
to get the biggest political "attraction" available to address their June graduates. The University is quite right

School of Medicine told a recent meeting of biologists how
the bacteria' that curdle and

"maple syrup disease."
The disease is incurable. Its
basic cause lies locked in the
infant's chromosomes, the tiny
cellular rods that carry life's
hereditary traits. The gene that
determines how the body metabolizes certain substances either
is distorted or is missing. The
ill effects of such genetic mistakes are smiled inborn errors of
metabolism.
Dr. John H. Menkes, assistant
professor of pediatrics at Johns
Hopkins, reported at the recent
meeting in Atlantic City of the
Federation of American Societies

amino acids. The chief biological
role of amino acids is to join
together to form protein molecules of different structures and
functions.
In maple syrup disease, the fat
material that makes up the
brain substance myelin seems to
get formed wrong. Defective
myelin means a defective nervous system because myelin is
thought to be the insulator of
nerve fibers and is needed for
successful transmission of nerve
impulses.
How can the germs that produce sour milk help scientists
understand a human disease?
The answer is in cell chemistry.
Every body cell stays alive about
